passages.text: Short vol is the last refugio for carry

Overview: Moves in DM rates have been mixed across jurisdictions since our last publication, although with a broad- based steepening of yield curves, especially in 5s/30s. GBP rates sold off, extending their underperformance given stronger- than- expected inflation data, while USD yields outperformed given the sharp rally and 5s/30s steepening after Powell's dovish remarks at Jackson Hole and renewed fears over Fed independence. A flare up in political noise in France led to a 10bp widening in the 10Y OAT spread to Bund, which has now settled around 80bp. We find this repricing of political uncertainty risk premia to be broadly fair. On the central bank side, the Riksbank remained on hold at \(2\%\) last week, with guidance remaining open for another cut. RBNZ cut by 25bp to \(3\%\) , in line with market consensus but against our call for a hold; we now expect 25bp eases in November and February, with the terminal rate at \(2.50\%\) .

Euro: We remain neutral on duration with a modest bullish bias on 10Y German yields. Stick with our current intra- EMU/ESSA strategy of low- beta OW with partial hedges with UW France/Italy and hold 1) OW 10Y Spain ( \(100\%\) ) vs Italy ( \(50\%\) ) and Germany ( \(50\%\) ), and 2) OW 10Y EU ( \(100\%\) ) vs France ( \(50\%\) ) and Germany ( \(50\%\) ). Hold 3s/10s Italy steepener vs Germany as a risk- off hedge. Receive Oct25 ECB ESTR. Stay received 1Yx1Y ESTR and hold 98.125/98.3125 Dec25 Euribor receiver spread versus selling OTM Dec25 Euribor put. Enter Z5/Z6 conditional bull steepener via Dec25 front and 1Y midcurve calls. Keep 2s/10s conditional bear steepener via 3M OTM payer. 10s/30s curve appears only marginally too steep vs fundamental drivers. Keep medium- term steepening bias. 1Yx1Y/15Yx15Y is too flat vs 2Yx2Y/10Yx10Y and beta- weighted box trade is attractive on RV considerations. Keep Sep25 Schatz ESTR swap spread widener. Stay tactically neutral on outright Bund spreads but favour Dec25 conditional Bund bull widener as a risk- off hedge. We recommend Bund/Buxl swap spread curve steepener as a proxy to 10s/30s swap curve steepener with attractive RV. Stay short 3Mx1Yx1Y) unhedged straddle. Enter 6Mx5Y/1Yx5Y equi- notional expiry curve steepener, which is short gamma/long vega at inception.

UK keep received Nov25 MPC OIS. Shift to modest bullish bias on 1Yx1Y SENA and front/reds SONIA curve flattening bias. Stay neutral 10Y gilt yields. 30Y gilt yields optically cheap, but we don't fade on uncertain supply/ demand dynamics. Keep 10s/30s gilt curve steepening bias given seasonals.
Japan: Expectations for another MoF's issuance adjustment led to the outperformance of 25Y this week. We explore the JGB futures roll- over outlook. Keep 10s/30s swap spread flattener.
Australia & New Zealand: Close the paid AUD- USD 2Yx2Y (IRS- SFR) position for a profit of \(+37.5\mathrm{bp}\) , stay paid Dec '25 RBA- FOMC OIS spread. Receive NZD 2s/5s IRS curve spread vs AUD.

Short vol is the last refuge for carry

- Moves in DM rates have been mixed across jurisdictions since our last publication, although with a broad-based steepening of yield curves, especially in 5s/30s. GBP rates sold off extending their underperformance given stronger-than-expected inflation data, while USD yields outperformed given the sharp rally and 5s/30s steepening 30s after Powell's dovish remarks at Jackson Hole and renewed fears over Fed independence. A flare up in political noise in France led to a 10bp widening in the 10Y OAT spread to Bund, which has now settled around 80bp. We find this repricing of political uncertainty risk premia to be broadly fair. On the central bank side, Riksbank remained on hold at 2% last week with guidance remaining open for another cut. RBNZ cut by 25bp to 3%, in line with market consensus but against our call for a hold; we now expect 25bp eases in November and February, with terminal rates at 2.50%.

Moves in DM rates have been mixed across jurisdictions since our last publication, although with a broad- based steepening of yield curves, especially in 5s/30s (Figure 1). GBP yields sold off- 5bp across the board, driven by better- than- expected data prints with July inflation notably surprising to the upside. US rates instead outperformed cross market, having rallied 10- 15bp at the front end with a sharp steepening in 5s/30s after Powell's dovish remarks at Jackson Hole and renewed fears over Fed independence.
Figure 1: Moves in DM rates have been mixed across jurisdictions since our last publication, although with a broad-based steepening of yield curves, especially in 5s/30s
Cumulative change in 5s/30s par Bund, Treasury and gilt curve; since 1 April 2025; bp
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Political noise flared up in the Euro space this week leading to a substantial spread widening move. Notably, 10Y OATs widened by around 10bp in a day after PM Bayrou surprisingly announced a confidence vote scheduled for 8 September (Figure 2). French 10Y spread to Bund has now settled around 80bp. We find the recent repricing of political uncertainty risk premia to be broadly fair and expect the 10Y France- Germany spread to stay in the 75- 85bp range over the coming weeks (see Euro Cash). Moreover, in the Netherlands, the current caretaker government survived a confidence vote on Wednesday after fears of a government collapse (new elections were already scheduled for 29 October), even though market reaction to this news was marginal.
Figure 2: 10Y OATs widened sharply this week given the increased chances that the current government will after the confidence vote surprisingly called by PM Bayrou on 8 September
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Next week, the data calendar will be in focus given the release of aggregate Euro area inflation numbers for August as well as US labour market prints (August employment report out on Friday).

In terms of strategy, in Euro space, we remain neutral on German duration while we keep received 1Yx1Y ESTR and tactically receive Oct25 ECB OIS. After the French spread widening this week, we close 10Y Belgium vs. France \((50\%)\) and Germany \((50\%)\) . We keep 10Y EU vs. France \((50\%)\) and Germany \((50\%)\) as well as long 10Y Spain vs. Italy \((50\%)\) and Germany \((50\%)\) . In the UK, we keep receiving Nov25 MPC OIS and have a \(10s / 30s\) gilt curve steepening bias. In the US, we continue to recommend \(5s / 20s\) steepeners.

The Riksbank remained on hold at \(2\%\) last week. The meeting delivery was broadly in line with expectations and guidance retained optionality for a September cut ("still some probability of a further cut this year"). The recent Swedish labour market data surprised to the downside and the August NIER survey supported our conviction that core inflation would fall below target in 2026, but 2Q GDP and retail sales out on Friday were marginally better than expected. Available fiscal space also surprised to the upside this week at 80bn (vs. our forecast of 60bn and NIER forecast of 34bn). Our economists are still calling for a final 25bp Riksbank cut in September, although the market is pricing a \(\sim 50\%\) probability of a cut (Figure 3). Next week's inflation data (4 September) will be key in determining if a September cut is likely or not.

The RBNZ cut policy rate last week by 25bp to \(3\%\) . This was in line with consensus and market pricing ( \(\sim 21\) bp before the meeting), but against our economists call for a hold. The overall meeting delivery was dovish with a 50bp cut also being floated as an option. The previous guidance about waiting for the peak in inflation to pass was abandoned to focus more on weaker- than- expected growth momentum. We had expected that weaker growth would lead RBNZ to cut, but only after staying on hold through 2H25. Given this week's shift, we bring forward our forecast for RBNZ cuts: we are now calling for 25bp eases in November and February, with the terminal rate at \(2.50\%\) (vs. \(2.75\%\) previously).
Global Markets Strategy Global Fixed Income Markets Weekly 29 August 2025

Since early August, intermediate OIS swaps have broadly sold off with 5Yx5Y SONIA notably re- testing the multi- year highs last seen in mid- May (Figure 4). 1Yx1Y/5Yx5Y GBP and EUR curves are hovering at steep levels ( \(\sim 100\mathrm{bp}\) ) and the USD curve has reached its steepest level ( \(\sim 110\mathrm{bp}\) ) after a sharp move last week following Powell's dovish remarks at Jackson Hole and renewed concerns over Fed independence (Figure 5). We provide an update of our models for intermediate swaps, curves and cross- market spreads.

Figure 4: Intermediate yields continued to sell off over the past couple of weeks with 5Yx5Y SONIA notably re-testing the highs seen in mid- May... Evolution of 5Yx5Y EUR (rhs), USD and GBP OIS yield; since 1 January 2025; bp
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Global Markets Strategy Global Fixed Income Markets Weekly 29 August 2025

Figure 5: ... 1Yx1Y/5Yx5Y GBP and EUR curves are hovering at steep levels and the USD curve has reached its steepest level ( \(\sim\) 110bp) following Powell's remarks at Jackson Hole last week and renewed Fed independence concerns
Evolution of 1Yx1Y/5Yx5Y EUR (rhs), USD and GBP OIS yield; since 1 January 2025; bp
Source: J.P. Morgan.

From a fundamental macro valuation perspective, 5Yx5Y EUR and USD swap forwards are broadly fair at current levels on our long- term growth and inflation FRI models (Figure 6 ). Intermediate GBP forwards are instead still screening excessively cheap on the long- run regression vs. UK growth and inflation forecast revisions, but we think this reflects ongoing elevated risk premia given fiscal constraints and the current likely shortfall in budget headroom. We think that market uncertainty around the UK fiscal outlook will persist, with noise likely to intensify around the Autumn Budget discussion, and we therefore do not look to fade the current cheapness in intermediate GBP rates.

Looking at curves, we note that, although the term premia steepness priced in 1Yx1Y/5Yx5Y OIS curves once we control for monetary policy expectations (proxied by 1Yx1Y OIS swaps) is lower relative to the peak levels seen after the tariff announcement of 2 April, it remains quite elevated, especially for GBP rates (Figure 7). The 1Yx1Y/5Yx5Y SONIA curve is indeed now over 40bp too steep on a 1Y regression vs. the level of 1Yx1Y SONIA.
Turning to cross- market spreads, 5Yx5Y USD vs. 5Yx5Y DM spreads are now screening fair relative to their respective 1Yx1Y OIS forward spreads on an RV basis (Figure 8).

French surprise disrupted summer carry

- German yields rallied with modest outperformance of the intermediate sector on the back of dovish Fed messaging and French politics back under the spotlight- We remain neutral on duration and maintain a modest bullish bias on 10Y German yields- We stick with our current intra-EMU/€-SSA strategy of low-beta OW with partial hedges with UW France/Italy for the time being- We find the recent repricing of political uncertainty risk premia in French spreads broadly fair- We expect the 10Y France-Germany spread to stay in 75-85bp range over the coming weeks until there is some clarity on the direction of the political developments- We strongly believe that the ongoing French political developments will remain a French idiosyncratic story unless we get the tail risk disruptive scenarios- Hold OW 10Y Spain (100%) vs. Italy (50%) and Germany (50%) and OW 10Y EU (100%) vs. France (50%) and Germany (50%)- Take profit on OW 10Y Belgium (100%) vs. France (50%) and Germany (50%)- Hold 3s/10s Italy steepener vs. Germany as a risk-off hedge- Supply: around €26bn of conventionals via auction next week in Germany, France and Spain; new 10Y France via auction

Since our last publication two weeks ago, German yields declined with a modest outperformance of the intermediate sector, with the dovish messaging from the Fed and the French politics being the main driver of the move (Figure 16). Cross- market, US yields outperformed, with chair Powell delivering a dovish speech at the Jackson Hole symposium further opening the door for a Fed cut in September.
Figure 16: German yields declined since our last publication two weeks ago on the back of dovish Fed messaging and French politics back under the spotlight

10Y German yields have rallied around 6bp over the past couple of weeks to the \(2.70\%\) and are at their average levels for the past month. DM market focus next week will be on US payrolls and implications for the Fed's reaction function but we note that over the past few months 10Y German yields have been non- directional with 10Y UST yields (Figure 17). We expect this lack of directionality to persist as ECB is effectively at where it sees the neutral- policy rate and our expectation of limited term premia to be priced in the intermediate sector of the German curve.

We remain neutral on duration and maintain a modest bullish bias on 10Y German yields and would look to fade any term- driven sell- off in the intermediate sector. However, from a relative valuation standpoint we note that the 2s/10s curve looks very modestly too flat vs. front end yields (1Yx1Y ESTR) and adjusting for the ECB balance sheet (Figure 18).

Figure 17: US payrolls are in focus next week, but we expect the lack of directionality between 10Y German and 10Y UST yields to persist 10Y par Germany yield regressed against 10Y UST benchmark yield; past 3M; %
Figure 18: We stay neutral duration with the 2s/10s curve very slightly too flat vs. the level of front end yields and adjusting for the ECB balance sheet
\\*2s/10s \(= -0.46^{*}1\mathrm{Yx}1\mathrm{Y}\) ESTR - 15.0ECB balance sheet \(+7.5;\) R-squared: \(92\%\) Source: J.P. Morgan

Intra- EMU spreads came under pressure since our last weekly in mid- August with most of the widening happening following the surprise confidence vote announcement by French PM Bayrou on Monday 25 August.

We have been recommending light outright OW intra- EMU/€- SSA exposures over summer as we didn't find the risk/reward attractive for carry exposures given limited carry/tight valuations and OW positioning. Also, we had preferred modest OW intra- EMU/€- SSA exposures with at least partial hedge vs. UW France or UW Italy to reduce beta to broader risk markets and benefit from any escalation in political noise in France. Our partial hedge strategy was vindicated over the past week given the escalation of political uncertainty in France. Given our expectation of ongoing political uncertainty in France over the coming weeks, we stick with our current intra- EMU/€- SSA strategy of low- beta OW with partial hedges with UW France/Italy for the time being (see French politics - scenarios and implications for the macro, rates and FX outlook, 28 Aug, for details of French political scenarios and market implications).

We strongly believe that the ongoing French political developments will remain a French idiosyncratic story unless we get the tail risk disruptive scenarios. We, therefore, expect limited contagion to rest of intra- EMU spreads, as has been the case during this week's widening.

On positioning, as per our latest client survey, 28 August, European real money investors modestly reduced their OW intra- EMU exposure, with current OW exposures still close to the highest levels seen since early- 2022 (Figure 19). The current OW positioning could expose intra- EMU spreads to near- term widening pressure on liquidations in the event of any further widening on French political uncertainty.

On issuance, after the typical summer lull, the pace of Euro area sovereign issuance has started to pick- up in the second half of August, slightly earlier than has been observed in recent years, and is expected to further increase in September in line with typical historical dynamics (Figure 20). Overall, we expect supply pressures over the rest of 2025 to be materially lower than 1H25 given strong issuance frontloading, with \(\sim 76\%\) gross issuance already covered.
Figure 19: European investors OW exposure is still close to the highest levels seen since early 2022 Net exposure of Euro area investors to peripherals vs. core, %
Source: J.P. Morgan European Client Survey, 28 August
Figure 20: Euro area sovereign issuance pace has started to pick-up in the second half of August and is expected to further increase in September in line with typical historical dynamics

We keep low beta OW exposures via OW 10Y Spain \((100\%)\) vs. 10Y Italy \((50\%)\) and 10Y Germany \((50\%)\) and OW 10Y EU \((100\%)\) vs. short 10Y France \((50\%)\) and 10Y Germany \((50\%)\) . This week we take profit on OW 10Y Belgium \((100\%)\) vs. short 10Y France \((50\%)\) and 10Y Germany \((50\%)\) . As a risk- off hedge, we keep 3s/10s Italy steepener vs. Germany.

French spreads widened sharply post the surprise confidence vote announcement by PM Bayrou on Monday evening with the 10Y France- Germany spread widening some 10bp to around 80bp. However, this is still below the wides of close to 90bp seen during peak political noise around 2025 budget in early January 2025. After the recent widening, 10Y France- Germany spread is now screening more than 10bp too wide on our fair value framework

(Figure 21), which in our view reflects the repricing of political uncertainty risk premia. Also based on our sovereign risk index (see 2025 Euro Cash Outlook for details of index), we find French spreads around 10bp too wide (Figure 22), reflecting similar political uncertainty risk premia. The confidence vote announcement was a surprise but as we outlined in our 2H25 outlook we had expected an increase in political noise and modest widening in French spreads at some point around 2026 budget discussions.
Figure 21: French spreads are now screening more than 10bp too wide on our fair value framework, reflecting heightened political uncertainty risk premia

Figure 23 below shows our estimates of 10Y France- Germany spread in a steady state over the next 1- 2 months under various political scenarios. From a market point of view the key focus will be the fiscal agenda under the various outcomes and from a big picture perspective we think the most likely outcomes would result in only modest fiscal slippage relative to our forecast. We stress that there is high uncertainty around the outcomes given the surprise confidence vote call, lack of polls and lack of clarity on party groupings/manifestos in case of an early election.

In our view, the most likely scenario in the event that the Bayrou government falls is Macron will try to nominate a new PM. If the newly nominated PM is able to survive a confidence vote in the parliament, then we believe 10Y France- Germany spread will likely remove most of the political risk premia currently priced in and move back to the 65- 75bp range seen over the past few months.

If a new lower house election is called, our judgement is that a RN relative majority will be the most likely outcome. However, given the relative majority, it is unclear if RN will be able to find external support to govern or will face no- confidence motion leading to a dysfunctional lower house. Under such a scenario, we believe it will be hard for RN to deliver a confrontational fiscal approach but we still expect the market to price ongoing political uncertainty risk premia with 10Y spread staying around 80bp. Under the less likely scenario

of RN absolute majority, we believe that RN will have a choice to make, to either decide to take a confrontational fiscal stance or to take a more prudent fiscal stance with the aim to have a strong showing at the 2027 Presidential election. Our bias is to assume that RN takes a prudent fiscal stance given the strong incentive of winning 2027 Presidential race and therefore under such a scenario we expect 10Y France- Germany spread to settle in 70- 80bp range. Clearly, if RN decides to take a confrontational fiscal approach, it would be quite disruptive.

In our view, the less likely scenarios of a left coalition government (either relative or absolute majority) are the most disruptive outcomes under a new lower house election scenario given their expansive fiscal agenda. We expect French spreads to come under significant pressure with 10Y France- Germany spread potentially widening beyond 100bp.

On the ratings front, France has a busy rating review calendar post summer (Figure 24). Fitch will be the first to review French sovereign rating on 12 September (current rating AA- negative outlook). Fitch had put France on negative outlook in October 2024. In their last rating review in March 2025, Fitch had forecast French deficit for 2026 at 5.6% and for 2027 at 5.4%. Also, in their recent commentary post the French 2026 draft proposal from the Bayrou government in July 2025, Fitch highlighted that the proposed budget (2026 deficit projected at 4.6% by the government) could improve fiscal outturns but given political constraints the government will find it hard to approve the proposal in full. Our base case is for no rating action from Fitch at the review, as by 12 September, it is unlikely to have much clarity on political/budget process and Fitch will likely want to see the final political/budget outcome before making a decision on a rating downgrade. A rating downgrade from AA- to A+ will be a modest surprise for the market, in our view, and would likely lead to some modest knee- jerk widening in French spreads (around 5bp in 10Y spread). For instance, Belgian spreads underperformed by around 4bp vs. core peers post the Fitch down

grade from AA- negative outlook to \(\mathrm{A + }\) stable outlook on 13 June 2025. A downgrade to \(\mathrm{A + }\) will have no direct index implications (in terms of exclusion) for the key bond indices, as per our understanding. A downgrade from AA to the A bucket (not our base case) could lead to some selling as some investors could have an internal hurdle rate with AA as a minimum rating threshold for investments. However, it is hard to estimate the magnitude of these flows given the lack of public data on these benchmarks.

Over the near term, we find the recent repricing of political uncertainty risk premia broadly fair in the French spreads and expect the 10Y France- Germany spread to stay in 75- 85bp range over the coming weeks till there is some clarity on the direction of the political developments. We have been recommending partly hedging our OW exposures in 10Y EU and 10Y Belgium with UW France over the past few months to benefit from any potential French political noise. These recommendations performed well over this week's French widening. We take profit on OW 10Y Belgium \((100\%)\) vs. short 10Y France \((50\%)\) and 10Y Germany \((50\%)\) (Figure 25). We keep OW 10Y EU \((100\%)\) vs. short 10Y France \((50\%)\) and 10Y Germany \((50\%)\) given our medium- term constructive EU outlook also.

The &STR 1Y forward yields see- sawed over the last two weeks on shifting risk sentiment, but are overall lower across the curve with a decent outperformance of the belly (Figure 36 ). A relatively dovish Fed rhetoric at Jackson Hole, where Chair Powell further opened the door for a September cut, and French political noise were the primary drivers of the rally. Anecdotal evidence suggests that flows were mixed with some real money receiving at the ultra- long end, which was broadly counterbalanced by hedge funds' interest in long- end steepeners.

The ESTR curve is currently pricing 0bp, 3bp, and 9bp of cumulative easing by September, October, and December meetings, respectively (Figure 37). Recently, ECB rhetoric has shifted in a hawkish direction, with the central bank being in a "good position" with respect to policy rates even though its easing bias remains (Figure 38). We agree that a September cut is not on the cards but we believe that a cut in October is a possibility even though market pricing of such a move is minimal. Our baseline is for ECB to deliver one final cut in October, although the bar for an ease is high. Recent media articles have mentioned that ECB sources see rates remaining on hold in September given growth has surprised to the upside, the EU- US trade deal is not causing "major economic concerns", and inflation data are in line with the June forecast (Figure 39).
Figure 38: ECB rhetoric has shifted in the hawkish direction over the past few weeks
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 39: A September cut is unlikely but we believe that October meeting should price more optionality of a cut
Source: J.P. Morgan.

However, our economists' call for an October cut is driven by several factors (see here). First, the ECB core inflation forecast is currently undershooting the \(2\%\) target for both 2026 & 2027 and is at target only for headline in 2027. Indeed, market pricing for HICP inflation

is also below target for the next few years, suggesting that an easing bias is likely appropriate (Figure 40). Second, the ECB June projections, which undershoots targets, factor in one more rate cut, which implies that two cuts would be needed to move the inflation projection up to \(2\%\) . Third, even though growth data has been better- than- expected, it has not overshot staff projections so far. It is likely that current ECB rhetoric embeds some tolerance for inflation prints undershooting the \(2\%\) target and that bar for an expected October is also high and will likely require further weakening in both growth and inflation data. Nevertheless, we also believe that market pricing around 3bp of easing for October is too low. We expect the ECB to stay on hold in September but not fully shut the door for an October cut. Thus, risk- reward for receiving Oct25 ECB ESTR is high with asymmetric upside, in our view. Overall, we recommend tactically receiving Oct25 ECB ESTR at \(1.895\%\) (see Trade Recommendations).

We continue to receive 1Yx1Y ESTR that we have been recommending for the past few weeks, which has moved in a narrow 7bp range since the ECB's July meeting (Figure 41). We acknowledge that the bar for a large rally in 1Yx1Y ESTR is high and we expect this rate to continue to range trade. While the upside to receiving is limited, we believe that this offers asymmetric upside from current levels, as the ESTR curve is only pricing a cumulative easing of around 20bp by mid- 2026. With the ECB still maintaining an easing bias, we believe that the market will continue to price some easing which is likely to increase if output were to start to weaken or inflation prints over the coming months are more benign than ECB's forecast. Thus, we see limited risk of a sharp sell- off in 1Yx1Y ESTR.
Along similar lines, we keep 98.125/98.3125 Dec25 Euribor call spread versus selling 98.0625 Dec25 Euribor put, which is also expected to benefit from the expected asymmetry in front- end yields.

The Euribor curve has flattened sharply over the past few days with Dec25/Dec26 flattening around 5bp since our last publication two weeks ago (Figure 42). We had turned tactically neutral on this curve two weeks ago. With the curve now inverted, we have a bias towards some steepening of the curve. We believe that if increased ECB easing expectations are priced into the curve it will likely be front loaded into 4Q25 or 1Q26. The Dec25/Dec26 curve exhibits a strong negative directionality versus yields and is currently too flat on a 3M

regression basis (Figure 43). We recommend Dec25/Dec26 conditional bull steepeners via Dec25 Euribor calls (front and 1Y midcurve calls) (see Trade Recommendations). Dec25 options on Dec25 futures (front options) are trading relatively cheap in implied volatility terms versus those on Dec26 futures (1Y midcurve options) which allows us to enter the trade at around 3bp better than forwards, after adjusting for net credit using ATM calls.

The 2s/10s swap curve overall flattened around 4bp with 10Y swap yields declining around 7bp. Further out the curve, the 10s/30s swap curve has continued the gradual steepening seen over 2025 and is now close to the steepest level seen since the ECB started its tightening cycle in early 2022 (Figure 44). The steepening over the last few months has been driven by a combination of structural and technical factors. For instance, increased correlation to US curve, positioning ahead of the Dutch pension fund transition from DB to DC schemes, which will require lesser and potentially shorter- dated hedges, have steepened the curve.

Interestingly, despite the recent steepening, the 10s/30s swap curve now appears only around 5bp too steep versus its fundamental drivers in our long- term fair value model versus appearing around 12- 15bp too steep a few weeks ago (Figure 45). This correction in the residual can be largely explained by the fact that the EUR swap curve has lagged the recent steepening of the USD curve, which has itself been driven by concerns around fiscal term premium and Fed independence (see here) (Figure 46).

Looking ahead, we have a steepening bias on the 10s/30s curve but refrain from outright positioning. Our medium term steepening bias is primarily supported by the fact that Dutch pension fund based flows will likely begin over the coming months as we get closer to the transition date of \(1^{\text{st}}\) Jan 2026 for a large majority of funds. We do caution that these funds are likely to be opportunistic in unwinding or reducing structural hedges and additionally have a 12M period to adjust their hedges post transition which would eliminate the need for immediate transition flows. Nevertheless, we note market participants will continue to anticipate these flows and potentially add to steepeners on any material flattening of the curve. Additionally, our steepening bias on the USD curve is supportive of Euro curve steepening even though the beta has declined.

On the other hand, some near- term flattening of the curve cannot be fully ruled out. For instance, Dutch pension funds typically announce indexation of pension payouts based on the September inflation print. With Dutch inflation still above \(2\%\) , we expect these funds to announce further increase in payouts this year. Historically, these funds then typically receive in long- end swaps (a 10s/30s flattener) to lock coverage ratios. A repeat of this dynamic could exert some flattening pressure on the curve. Of course, there exists a nontrivial chance that, due to already high policy funding ratios and high interest rate hedge exposures, indexation- based receiving could be smaller than seen previously. Nevertheless, this remains a risk to medium- term steepeners. Empirically, the 10s/30s curve tends to flatten a few bps over the month of September (Figure 47).

A few weeks ago, we had favoured 2Yx2Y/10Yx10Y swap curve steepener versus 10s/30s flattener on a beta- adjusted basis on RV considerations. The 2Yx2Y/10Yx10Y swap curve now appears 3bp too steep versus 10s/30s and we turn neutral on this relative steepening bias (Figure 48). Instead, we now find 1Yx1Y/15Yx15Y swap curve too flat versus 2Yx2Y/10Yx10Y and favour 1Yx1Y/15Yx15Y swap curve steepeners versus a beta- weighted amount of 2Yx2Y/10Yx10Y steepeners on RV considerations (Figure 49).

German swap spreads have exhibited limited volatility in the latest OAT/Bund spread widening episode, which was driven by PM Bayrou's call for a confidence vote. Specifically, current volatility of swap spreads pales significantly in comparison to the sharp increase seen during the surprise election announcement in June 2024. As we have discussed here.

we find the recent repricing of political uncertainty risk premia in French spreads to be broadly fair. More importantly, we expect the 10Y OAT/Bund spread to stay in a 75- 85bp range until there is further clarity on the direction of political developments. In our view, the limited volatility of German swap spreads potentially embeds this expectation of limited volatility in French spreads. Nevertheless, in the event of a large widening of French spreads, we would expect German swap spreads to widen as well, despite limited correlation currently. In Figure 52, we show the betas of various German swap spreads versus 10Y OAT/Bund spreads during past episodes of sharp widening in French spreads. While the relationship is currently broadly non- existent, historically, German swap spreads tend to exhibit a decent beta (and R- squared) to French spreads during these two episodes. For instance, Schatz spreads moved with a beta of around 50% to French spreads during the sharp widening seen in June 2024 when Macron surprisingly announced the parliamentary elections. Admittedly, the reaction of German swap spreads this time around has been rather muted but we believe that Schatz swap spread widener still offers a good hedge against a tail risk of significant widening in French spreads.

Additionally, conditional Bund bull wideners also offer attractive risk- off hedges against any escalation in risk- off sentiment. Bund spreads continue to exhibit a strong negative directionality versus yields, which will likely exacerbate if yields decline rapidly on any risk- off move. The options market is not pricing recent directionality (implied directionality of around \(17\%\) versus delivered directionality of around \(35\%\) ) (Figure 54). We favour tactical Dec25 Bund bull widener as a risk- off hedge.

In addition to the volatility of French spreads, the evolution of issuance will also be a shortterm driver of intermediate spreads. As seen in Figure 55, swapped issuance activity tends to pick up pace towards the end of August and continues on over the next few weeks. Issuance activity this time around is broadly following historical patterns and we expect this to continue increasing over the coming weeks; we also show the typical monthly averages of these swapped issuance activity across the calendar year versus that seen in 2025. All else equal, this increase in swapped issuance activity over the coming weeks should exert a narrowing pressure on intermediate swap spreads. However, as we have discussed at length before, pre- positioning in anticipation of these flows tends to lead to narrower spreads already before issuance picks up. Bund spreads typically exhibit some volatility around endAugust/September while maintaining the overall broad narrowing trend (Figure 56). While this is supportive of a modest narrowing bias, we refrain from outright positioning given lingering risks around French politics and also going into US payroll data next week (see above).

Instead, we recommend Bund/Buxl swap spread curve steepener as an alternative. The Bund/Buxl swap spread curve has flattened around 4- 5bp over the month of August. On a short- term basis, the swap spread curve appears too flat versus 10s/30s swap curve, after adjusting for Bund spreads and the US tariff announcement in early April (Figure 57). Our medium- term swap spread steepening bias is supportive of swap spread curve steepening positions as well. Overall, we recommend Dec25 Bund/Buxl swap spread curve steepener (see Trade Recommendations).

Implied volatility declined marginally across the curve with a small flattening of the volatility curve across tails over the past two weeks (Figure 58). Anecdotal evidence suggests that flows were light with bias towards short volatility positions. 1M delivered volatility also declined around 0.3- 0.5bp/day across the curve which essentially reflects the large move post July ECB moving out of the sample. 1M delivered volatility is still around 0.6- 0.8bp/day below current implies across the curve (Figure 59).

Implieds are now at their YTD lows; they have declined broadly in a monotonic fashion since the spike around Trump's tariff announcement in early April with a decent steepening of the curve across tails (Figure 60). Implieds are optically cheap on valuations but we expect implieds to remain sticky around current levels. However, we continue to stay short volatility, especially via structures that exploit mean reversion in front- end yields (Figure 61). Admittedly, we have a bullish duration bias (see above) but we highlight that we do not expect front- end yields to decline materially from current levels and range trading remains a strong conviction theme. The bar for ECB to cut policy rates further is high and it will require proof of data which is likely to be gradual over the coming weeks, as is reflected in our baseline scenario of a final cut coming only in October. In other words, even though implied volatility is likely to remain sticky, we do expect delivered volatility to stay muted over the coming weeks. To this effect, we highlight the following attractive strategies.

Figure 62: ...and we stay short 3Mx(1Yx1Y) unhedged straddles Current implied vol (bp/day), straddle premium (bp of notional), breakeven moves (bp), and upper/lower breakeven levels \((\%)\)

First, we hold short in 3Mx(1Yx1Y) unhedged straddles - a theme that we have been following over the past few months and re- struck into new 3M options in our last publication (see here). As we had highlighted, the breakeven ranges are wide and will require material shift in ECB policy rate path expectations for yields to breach these levels (Figure 62).

Second, we also like expiry curve steempers on front/intermediate tails (2- 10Y). For instance, buying ATMF 1Yx5Y straddles versus selling an equi- notional amount of ATMF 6Mx5Y straddles are long vega/short gamma at inception by construction. The weighted implied volatility spread (weighted by vega to obtain equi- notional exposure) exhibits a strong positive correlation to implieds but with a small beta (Figure 63). The weighted vol spread is close to the low end of its recent range and appears marginally too cheap versus implies. On the curve, we prefer these structures in the 5Y sector where we expect delivered volatility to be relatively muted as ECB is expected to remain on the sidelines over the next few weeks. The main risk to this trade would come from a jump in risk- off sentiment which could lead to some flattening of the expiry curve and/or large yield moves. Overall, we recommend buying 1Yx5Y ATMF straddles versus selling an equi- notional amount of 6Mx5Y ATMF straddles (see Trade Recommendations).

Source: J.P. Morgan.

Third, we favour short synthetic forward volatility structures constructed using a triangle of swaptions. As we have discussed previously, these synthetic replicates have residual gamma and vega exposures even though standard forward volatility agreements (FVA) have zero gamma exposure. In Figure 64, we present a list of attractive synthetic volatility constructs that are overall short gamma/long vega at inception. We also highlight that short FVAs are short correlation by construction. Correlation between the front and intermediate yields (say 1Yx1Y vs 5Yx5Y) is around \(60\%\) when measured on daily changes over the past 3M. However, with front- end yields expected to remain sticky, we believe that risk bias for the correlation to stay low or decline even further. Amongst the structures presented, we favour shorts in 6Mx1Yx5Y which can be constructed via selling 6Mx1Y and 18Mx5Y straddles versus buying 6Mx6Y straddles, which appears attractive.

Domestic data over the past couple of weeks has increasingly challenged expectations of further BoE easing this year. Last week, headline CPI printed at \(3.8\%\) oya, in line with BoE expectations, but the underlying details showed sizeable price gains in food prices and core services, two categories the BoE is specifically focused on, with food inflation surprising to the upside in July ( \(4.9\%\) oya vs \(4.7\%\) BoE forecast). The PMI continues to indicate a weak jobs market, but the stronger than expected flash PMI for August suggests upside risks to our 3Q GDP forecast of \(0.8\%\) q/q annualised. GfK's consumer confidence reading for August also rose, suggesting household spending is not as weak as feared.

Our economist's call remains for a 25bp cut in November and a further 25bp cut in February, but we acknowledge the bar for a November ease has moved higher. We think a combination of a large downshift in wage growth and further declines in employment growth, alongside clear signs of weaker- than- expected headline and food inflation in September, are needed for the BoE to ease in November. Tighter fiscal policy at the Autumn budget would likely pose downside growth risks into 2026, but given the OBR needs 10 weeks to prepare forecasts and with no budget date announced yet, it is more likely that an Autumn budget will be delivered after the November \(6^{\mathrm{th}}\) MPC meeting. MPC OIS prices around 5bp of easing for November, a cumulative 10bp by the end of this year and just about 25bp of easing by next March (Figure 66). We keep received Nov25 MPC OIS given the limited easing priced as we wait to see labour market and inflation data over the coming months, but we do see a heightened chance that the BoE skips easing in November.

1Yx1Y SONIA is modestly higher over the past few weeks and is just above the \(3.60\%\) level, close to the highs since early June. Current levels look modestly cheap vs our expected BoE terminal rate of \(3.50\%\) and are around 18bp cheap on a relative basis vs 1Yx1Y SOFR (Figure 67), with over 130bp of Fed easing priced by the end of 2026 and 1Yx1Y SOFR just above \(3.0\%\) , its lowest level since October 2024. However, the relationship between 1Yx1Y SONIA and 1Yx1Y SOFR has been weakening over the past few months (Figure 68). We think the BoE could still ease policy rates in 1Q26, even if it skips a November ease, and still see neutral at around \(3.50\%\) , which likely limits how much 1Yx1Y SONIA can cheapen. We shift to a bullish bias on 1Yx1Y SONIA as we expect 1Yx1Y SONIA to range- trade around the \(3.50 - 3.55\%\) level.

10Y gilt yields are slightly higher over the past two weeks, having sold off to around 4.75% before falling back to just above the 4.70% level. The date for an Autumn budget has not yet been announced, and will likely be mid- November at the earliest, but the past couple of weeks have seen the government float various tax- raising ideas to plug the current fiscal shortfall, including introducing capital gains on the sale of primary residences, lowering the tax- free lump sum withdrawal threshold of pension savings and applying National Insurance to landlord's rental income. Details are far from clear, but applying some or all of these
along with freezing income tax thresholds from 2029 could raise \(\sim \pm 15\mathrm{bn}\)

This would likely plug a large part of our estimated £20bn budget shortfall, but we think this would be unlikely to materially reduce fiscal term premia uncertainty currently priced into the curve. In our view, unless the budget headroom is significantly increased above the £10bn from the prior budget then markets will be wary of how quickly any small headroom rebuild could be eroded again into a spring Budget if yields were to rise and/or GDP continue to undershoot OBR forecasts. 10Y gilt yields are towards the top end of their 3M ranges, but from a relative valuation standpoint 10Y gilt yields look close to fair value on a cross- market basis vs 10Y USTs and adjusting for relative 2Yx1Y SONIA- 2Yx1Y SOFR spread (Figure 70). The upcoming syndication of a new Oct2035 gilt expected next week will provide an interesting gauge of investor appetite for intermediate gilts against the backdrop of the recent fiscal noise. We stay neutral on 10Y duration.

Further out the curve, 30Y gilt yields are close to \(5.6\%\) and are at multi- decade highs (since 1998) with gilt forwards in the 15- 30Y sector of the curve well above the \(6.0\%\) level (Figure 71); however, we don't see current levels offering much value given the absence of structural investor demand. The 10s/30s gilt curve is little changed over the past couple of weeks and remains at multi- year steep levels, but we retain a 10s/30s steepening bias.

Figure 72: Historically, the 10s/30s gilt curve has exhibited seasonal steepening around the start of September, in contrast to the 10s/30s Bund and UST curves
Source: J.P. Morgan.

We note that the 10s/30s gilt curve has on average exhibited seasonal steepening from the start of September over the past five years, whereas the 10s/30s Bund and 10s/30s UST curves have tended to flatten (Figure 72). This likely reflects a typical pick- up in long- end gilt issuance after the summer hull. On a relative basis, we note that the 10s/30s gilt curve remains too steep on our valuation framework vs the level of 1Yx1Y SONIA, 30Y gilt yields and adjusting for the 10s/30s gilt curve (Figure 73), close to its steepest relative levels since late 2024. The DMO announced the issuance calendar from October - December on Friday, which will see two outright auctions at the long end of the curve and a planned 15Y syndication (Figure 74), in addition to the two long- end auctions scheduled in September. Long- end supply/demand dynamics remain unclear, in our view, and given the seasonal dynamics
and the potential for fiscal/issuance term premia uncertainty to remain elevated ahead of the autumn budget, we do not look to fade the outright and relative steepness in the 10s/30s gilt curve.

- The Nikkei reported on Thursday that the MoF distributed a questionnaire for the September Primary Dealer Meeting, which included proposals to reduce the size of the 15.5-39Y liquidity-enhancement auction from (1) JPY350bn per auction to JPY250bn or (2) JPY350bn to zero.

- If the MoF decides to reduce the issuance size by JPY100bn per auction, it would translate to a JPY0.6tn decrease in net supply per year in the 10Y+ sector. Conversely, if the MoF halts the issuance, it would reduce net supply by JPY2.1tn per year in the sector. Before accounting for any issuance adjustment, we forecast net issuance in the 10Y+ sector to be around JPY9tn in the next 12 months. Therefore, even with another round of reduction, the outstanding balance of super-long JGBs in the market will grow, led by the 30-year sector. From a net issuance perspective, we do not believe the reported reduction plan will be a game-changer. That said, the latest development highlights the MoF's willingness to take action to balance supply and demand. Given the state of off-the-runs in the long end, we believe a decrease in the size of 15.5-39Y liquidity-enhancement auction will be helpful.

- From a valuation perspective, the broad JGB curve does not appear to be excessively steep compared to its fundamental drivers. In the near term, politics poses an event risk. In our view, if the LDP decides to hold an early leadership contest, considering the market's expectations and reaction function, it may weigh on the long end of the curve. Accordingly, we maintain a cautious stance for now.
- We published JGB Futures Rollover Outlook (Sep 2025/Dec 2025): Meet our new friend, JJA.

- JBU5/JBZ5: We anticipate that the JBU5/JBZ5 calendar spread will follow the recent rollover pattern. As we near the peak of rollover activity, typically from around LTD-3, the calendar spread is expected to rise and reach the upper bound of our anticipated range. After the peak, we project the spread to decline to around the lower end of the range. Overall, we forecast the trading range of the calendar spread to be between 96 and 106 sen.

- JAU5/JJAZ5: Overall, we believe that positioning considerations are already reflected in the price, as suggested by our net basis analysis. We forecast the trading range of the calendar spread to be between 82 and 99 sen.

Over the past two weeks, JPY rates have risen in a modest bear- steepening manner (Figure 77). However, expectations for the MoF's issuance adjustment have partially reversed the sell- off at the back end of the curve this week, led by off- the- runs. Nonetheless, on a high level, super- long JGB yields are now trading above their highs recorded in late May, and unlike the April/May sell- off, which was exacerbated by skewed positioning, the recent rise in super- long yields has been a gradual repricing process.

As we previously highlighted, the 25- year sector has contributed to the heaviness, with some bond prices nearing 50 yen, raising concerns about potential selling by lifers to avoid impairment (Figure 78). While we believe lifers are buying on- the- run 30- year JGBs at the same time, sales involving off- the- runs typically weigh more due to a greater supply- demand imbalance.

Additionally, the JsDA transactions data for July indicates a decline in foreign sponsorship for \(10Y + \text{JGBs}\) (Figure 79). Although the MoF's weekly transactions data show that international investors have been net buyers of long- term bonds lately, it is unclear if their buying flows have been in the super- long sector. With a limited number of sizable buyers, any slowdown in foreign demand could disrupt the delicate supply- demand balance.

In this context, the Nikkei reported on Thursday that the MoF distributed a questionnaire for the September Primary Dealer Meeting, which included proposals to reduce the size of the 15.5- 39Y liquidity- enhancement auction from (1) JPY350bn per auction to JPY250bn or (2) JPY350bn to zero. The article states that a reduction would be offset by increasing the size of the 1- 5Y liquidity- enhancement auction. While the composition of liquidity- enhancement auctions has been discussed at almost every Primary Dealer Meeting, in our view, it is noteworthy that the proposals do not include an option to maintain the amount steady.

If the MoF decides to reduce the auction size by JPY100bn per auction, it would translate to a JPY0.6tn decrease in net supply per year in the 10Y+ sector. Conversely, if the MoF halts the issuance, it would reduce net supply by JPY2.1tn per year in the sector. Before accounting for any issuance adjustment, we forecast net issuance in the 10Y+ sector to be around JPY9tn in the next 12 months (Figure 80). Therefore, even with another round of reduction, the outstanding balance of super- long JGBs in the market will grow, led by the 30- year sector. From a net issuance perspective, we do not believe the reported reduction plan will be a game- changer.

Nonetheless, the latest development highlights the MoF's willingness to take action to balance supply and demand. Given the state of off- the- runs in the long end, we believe a decrease in the size of the 15.5- 39Y liquidity- enhancement auction will be helpful.

Outstanding in the market

From a valuation perspective, the broad JGB curve does not appear to be excessively steep compared to its fundamental drivers (Figure 81). In the near term, politics poses an event risk. This Wednesday, various major media outlets reported that the LDP's Presidential Election Administration Committee is expected to begin the process of deciding on whether to hold the leadership contest once the analysis of the upper house election is announced at the meeting next Tuesday. According to reports from NHK and other major outlets, the deadline for submitting requests for an early contest is expected to be September 8, with the decision on whether to hold it likely to be made in early September.

Recent public polls show that the approval rating for the Ishiba administration is on a recovery trend. Compared to immediately after the upper house election, the market's interest in political headlines and concerns around fiscal policy have receded. In our view, if the LDP decides to hold an early leadership contest, considering the market's expectations and
reaction function, it may weigh on the long end of the curve. Accordingly, we maintain a cautious stance for now.

Rolling down the curve, 1y1y OIS has been trading stably around the upper end of its recent range, and BoJ dates now imply a nearly \(50\%\) probability of a 25bp hike by October, and a \(92\%\) probability by January (Figure 82). Deputy Governor Himino is set to speak next Tuesday, which we think is a potential event risk, as he leans on the more hawkish end of the spectrum. That said, even if his speech leaves a market impact, it is more likely to affect the pricing of medium- term policy expectations rather than near- term pricing, considering his past speech on real interest rates.

As we approach the last trading day (LTD) for the front contracts of JBU5 and JJAU5 on September 12, we anticipate that the market's near- term focus will be predominantly on rollover transactions. This analysis is based on data available up to the market close on August 28.

Our mechanical net basis analysis indicates that the theoretical value of the calendar spread as of August 28 was 110.5 sen, which was 9.5 sen higher than the actual market close of 101.0 sen. However, we believe that the repo rate for the back contract is low, given the possibility of an October hike, which suggests a bearish/narrowing bias. Taking this into account, we anticipate an overall neutral bias on the calendar spread.

Overall, we believe the current positioning landscape mirrors the previous rollover. We anticipate that the calendar spread will rise as we approach the peak of rollover activity (typically from around LTD- 3), since investors such as CTAs and bear funds, who cannot settle by physical delivery, will roll. After this peak, we expect the spread to decline as proprietary accounts that can handle physical delivery will roll, and any remaining long rollovers take place.

We anticipate that the JBUS/JBZ5 calendar spread will follow the recent rollover pattern. As we near the peak of rollover activity, typically from around LTD- 3, the calendar spread is expected to rise and reach the upper bound of our anticipated range. After the peak, we project the spread to decline to around the lower end of the range. Overall, we forecast the trading range of the calendar spread to be between 96 and 106 sen (closed at 101 sen on August 28) (Figure 83).

The minutes to the RBA's August meeting skewed dovish, though came and went with little fanfare. The decision to lower the cash rate by 25bp was unanimous, while there remains general agreement that "some further reduction in the cash rate over the coming year" would likely be required to achieve the central bank's employment/inflation objectives. The subsequent discussion steps through the merits of a "gradual" versus "slightly faster" pace of easing, but comes to the conclusion "it was not yet possible to judge between these alternative scenarios for the pace of future reduction in the cash rate, given the prevailing uncertainties".

Based on JPM Hawk Dove Scores (NLP summary) the minutes marked an incremental dovish shift relative to July (Figure 86), though still slightly more hawkish than May's meeting, where the RBA discussed easing policy by 50bp. From a cross market perspective, August's dovish tilt preserves the RBA- RBNZ HDS spread following the latter's surprisingly dovish commentary at its August meeting (Figure 87). In previous research we've explored the correlation of cross- market HDS using PCA and found most central bank commentary follows a common single factor (principal component (PC)1), which appears to act as a proxy for inflation. Unsurprisingly, RBA and RBNZ HDS have been very closely correlated with
PC1 in recent years given the surge in inflation resulted in broadly similar policy responses across DM central banks.

PC2 more closely aligns with a 'Follow the Fed' indicator, at least outside the periods where the Fed is very dovish. Interestingly, the RBA and RBNZ have historically displayed a relatively low correlation with PC2 (Figure 88), a relationship which has persisted in recent years despite the commonality in policy drivers (i.e. inflation). In our view these correlations will be preserved in coming quarters, with the Fed forecast to ease policy by 100bp over the next four meetings (4x25bps), outpacing the RBA (1x25bp) and RBNZ (2x25bp).

Our portfolio is already positioned to capture these dynamics. We close our paid AUD- USD 2Yx2Y (IRS- SFR) position for a profit of \(+37.5\) bp given this spread is now realigning with the previous range. We remain paid Dec '25 RBA- FOMC OIS and expect this trade to benefit from Australia's firmer growth outlook and greater fiscal capacity, both of which take pressure off monetary policy. These macro factors also support flattening on a domestic (RBA under- delivering) and cross- market (fading real term premia) basis, with Australia's 3s/10s curve steep in outright terms and versus the US (Figure 89).

The August minutes also included an update on the Bank's thinking around balance sheet size and asset composition. To date, the Bank has maintained a passive approach to balance sheet management, allowing bond holdings to run down as they mature but reviewing the appropriateness of this method on a periodic basis. The August minutes took a slightly different turn, noting that in the "absence of persuasive arguments from either a policy or a risk- reduction perspective, the Board determined that bond holdings should continue to run down as they mature and that this matter no longer warranted active consideration".

The RBA was widely expected to maintain a passive approach regarding its balance sheet, though this week's announcement shoots down any residual prospect of a more activist QT program. With that in mind, the RBA's balance sheet adjustment has been one of the more rapid across DM economies, with the expiration of the Term Funding Facility (TFF) reducing the RBA's balance sheet/excess reserves by \(\sim\) A\$200 billion since 2023 (Figure 90). We expect the pace of adjustment will slow from here, but given the RBA's bond holdings are concentrated in the shorter- dated lines (Figure 91) the balance sheet is still on track to halve in size by late- 2028.

Australia's monthly CPI indicator for July printed at \(2.8\%\) oya (Figure 92), significantly stronger than our forecast \((2.3\%\) oya) and underpinned by an unexpected spike in electricity prices \((13\% \mathrm{m / m})\) . Electricity prices have swung wildly in the past two years following the implementation of government cost of living subsidies, with this week's reported price spike owing to the next installment landing in August, rather than July. (Figure 93). Accordingly, out- of- pocket costs for households in these regions should revert lower in the next print, taking some of the heat off the headline CPI print.

Despite the magnitude of the forecast miss, we don't think this week's print has material implications for monetary policy with the RBA likely to look through the July data. Indeed, if our view on subsidies is correct then household electricity costs in NSW/ACT should decline in August as payments resume. Further, inflation is still target consistent and aligned with our view for a rebound to the upper half of the band.

Breakevens were little changed this week (Figure 94), with the short- dated lines pushing wider, the belly unchanged, and a small narrowing in the long- end. Accordingly, our view on the curve hasn't changed in the wake of the minutes or monthly CPI indicator, and we continue to favour widening expressions in the belly/longer dated lines which still screen cheap relative to the RBA's inflation target.

On a cross- market basis, front- end spreads remain deeply negative and reflect the largely idiosyncratic tariff shock expected to hit US goods prices. The belly and longer dated lines have widened from recent tights, but remain low in the range which may reflect more of Australia's beta to (negative) global demand shocks playing out in real yields, rather than BEI. Our bias is for modest breakeven outperformance in the 2040 and 2050 lines given the respective central bank inflation targets, though levels are admittedly less compelling than earlier in the year.

Ratings System: J.P. Morgan uses the following issuer portfolio weightings for Emerging Markets Sovereign Research: Overweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to outperform the relevant index, sector, or benchmark credit returns); Marketweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to perform in line with the relevant index, sector, or benchmark credit returns); and Underweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to underperform the relevant index, sector, or benchmark credit returns). NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating for this security because of either legal, regulatory or policy reasons or because of lack of a sufficient fundamental basis. The previous rating no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. NC is Not Covered. An NC designation is not a rating or a recommendation. Recommendations will be at the issuer level, and an issuer recommendation applies to all of the index- eligible bonds at the same level for the issuer. When we change the issuer- level rating, we are changing the rating for all of the issues covered, unless otherwise specified. Ratings for quasi- sovereign issuers in the EMBIG may differ from the ratings provided in EM corporate coverage.

Valuation & Methodology: For J.P. Morgan's Emerging Markets Sovereign Research, we assign a rating to each sovereign issuer (Overweight, Marketweight or Underweight) based on our view of whether the combination of the issuer's fundamentals, market technicals, and the relative value of its securities will cause it to outperform, perform in line with, or underperform the credit returns of the EMBIG index over the next three months. Our view of an issuer's fundamentals includes our opinion of whether the issuer is becoming more or less able to service its debt obligations when they become due and payable, as well as whether its willingness to service debt obligations is increasing or decreasing.

series.name: Data Points
series.values: Multiple data points are scattered across the chart, forming a cloud-like distribution. A regression line Y = -0.03 X1 + 0.43 with R² = 53% is also present.

values.Comment: European Central Bank officials are increasingly convinced they can keep interest rates unchanged in September, according to people familiar with the matter who don't see the trade deal between Brussels and Washington causing major economic concerns.
I think the bar is high. So it needs a lot to convince me to change monetary policy.
Inflation is for now in a good place. Any insurance cut just for its own sake wouldn't be necessary though the ECB must of course be mindful of the risks.
We've seen good news, we've seen bad news, but not sufficiently big news to lead to a rethink of what we would need to do. I think we are still in a good place.

Higher levies will only have a small impact on GDP. The economy is increasingly back to potential. Growth is relatively modest, but resilient and on its way up with the fundamentals such as consumption and investment looking good at the moment. The ECB expects only a very minor impact on inflation from the trade deal.

Uncertainty about the effects of geopolitics and the trade war nevertheless clouds the economic outlook. Inflation is in the short term slowing below the 2% target as a result of cheaper energy, a stronger euro, and the slowdown in services inflation.
